Trump Gives Pentagon More Leeway To Wage War In The Middle East "The level of micromanagement ..." Advertisement - story continues below 
The American military is off its leash in the embattled Middle East. 
Unlike the Obama administration, who insisted many operational details be subject to review by White House aides, President Donald Trump has given those in the midst of the fighting more authority to respond as they see fit. 
“ Jim Mattis has been given the latitude to conduct military operations in the way he sees best,” Pentagon spokesman Chris Sherwood said. Advertisement - story continues below Senate Passes Resolution Blocking Obama-Era Internet ‘Power Grab’ 
Sherwood added that the overall strategy of working “by, with and through” local forces hasn’t changed. 
“This was an authority that was delegated by the president, through the secretary of defense to the Central Command commander to carry out,” said Pentagon spokesman Jeff Davis. 
“I don’t want to telegraph future operations, but this is part of a plan to go after a very real threat, to ensure they are defeated and denied the opportunity to plot and carry out terrorist attacks from ungoverned spaces,” Davis said in discussing plans for future raids in Yemen, the site of a controversial January raid that gained valuable intelligence but resulted in the death of Navy SEAL William “Ryan” Owens. Advertisement - story continues below 
“I don’t want to tip our hand too much on what these authorities are, because in doing so that will allow our enemy to know what might be coming as well,” Davis added. 
Even Trump critic Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., has voiced frustration with the short leash the former administration gave the military. 
“We don’t have to ask the 30-something-year-olds for permission to respond to an attack in Afghanistan,” he said. 
Rep. Mac Thornberry, R-Texas, said that while on a visit to Afghanistan during Obama’s presidency, he overheard a call from a National Security Council NSC staff member asking how much fuel was in the planes on the runway. Advertisement - story continues below Federal Judge Sides With Trump On Immigration Executive Order 
“The level of micromanagement was incredible, and of course by the time you work your way through the NSC process your target has moved,” he said. 
Jon B. Alterman , the director of the Middle East Program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said the administration faced a delicate calculation over how much authority to cede to the generals. 
“One extreme,” he said, is “giving 20-somethings in the White House veto power over generals in the field.” 
That should be avoided, he said, as should tactical decisions devoid of strategy. 
“… if you’re going to target and kill someone, there needs to be some kind of process to ensure that it serves a strategic purpose. We shouldn’t be comfortable with the other extreme, essentially handing out death sentences without much deliberation,” he added. 
One expert noted that regardless of who makes the call, Trump bears the responsibility. 
“It is reasonable for the White House to determine which decisions they need to be part of and which ones they are comfortable deferring to the Pentagon,” said Derek Chollet, an assistant secretary of defense in the Obama administration. “But a president has to think very carefully about this, because he may choose to delegate authority, but he cannot absolve himself of responsibility.” 
One general hoping for more freedom is Gen. Thomas Waldhauser , who heads the United States Africa Command and wants more flexibility targeting Shabaab militants in Somalia. 
“It allows us to prosecute targets in a more rapid fashion,” he said, stating that the goal is not to increase civilian casualties. 
“The cardinal rule in these types of engagements is to not make more enemies than you already have,” Waldhauser said. “We are not going to turn Somalia into a free-fire zone.” What do you think?
